ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: (Question 6) I found the fire ecology section most interesting. The second half the course about policy became a bit repetitious.(Question 9) I wish we could do more in the forest with prescribed burn and seeing the effect of fire on the landscape. Even if conditions were not perfect for burning, it would be good to go out and see old burns and the impacts fire had on the vegetation.
great group of people with strong interest in the subject matter, good discussion.
Going on the field trip at the end. I also enjoyed looking up my own articles and the seminar style class discussions we held.

The best things about the course was its communal atmosphere. The class was small and individual students developed a good rapport. Ann was instrumental in setting this tone, and it certainly contributed to my learning. The field trip was also great, though it would have been better if the burn hadn't been rained out by a freak hailstorm.
Learning from TA and classmates who have on the ground experience with wild land fire.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: the format of the class could be improved through some simple measures:-split up the lecture classes more evenly throughout the year. the student led discussions lost momentum when we had to be in charge of too many classes without a break. towards the end of the class, we ended up talking about the same thing because we didn't have any new influx of information via lecture-assign a textbook (or just a few chapters from a textbook on v2 in pdf form) for the science part of the class and expect students to get up to snuff on the basics of fire science on their own so you can devote more time in class to other aspects of fire (social, political, privatization, etc)-definitely incorporate guest lectures evenly throughout the course too (whether via skype/gotomeeting, bringing someone in, or having yale faculty and students come talk to us).
As mentioned above, more going out into the field and seeing the effect of fire on the landscape.

There was little that needed particular improvement; I'm grasping here. Perhaps some of the discussions could have been more focused/had a little more structure. I sometimes felt we were just wandering around without much thought to where we were going.
There wasn't enough course material to last the whole semester. Class needed more structure and more material.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were willing and able to help when called upon. I went to both for different concerns.
I didn't contact either in person during the term for my own reasons, but they were very available if I had reached out.
Both were helpful

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am very interested in the ecological and human dimensions of wildland fire. I think it is an important course to continue teaching at FES.
This fits in with my desire to work with public land management and policy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: As an elective and because my academic interests focuses on wildland fire.
I wanted a more practically focused course on an aspect of land management. I am also very interested in fire as topic -- a little bit of a pyromaniac, I guess.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes. I found the fire ecology part of the course very informative. I would have enjoyed more about the policy and human dimensions side.

The course certainly lived up to my expectations. I really enjoyed being in class with people who had spent time actually working on fires and other aspects of resource management. I learned a lot about wildfire and feel much better prepared to discuss it and arguefor its role on landscapes. I'm also much better aware of the challenges it poses.
I did not learn as much from the class as I expected

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes. It was very useful for my academic interests.
I did. I expected to gain an understanding of fire and get experience in a course that dealt with practical aspects of land management, and I did.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You get out of this course what you put into it. It is not too challenging, but very interesting material if you let yourself get absorbed by the information.
Enjoy it, and go on the field trip!
